newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corporate bond new issuance to perk up.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corporate bond new issuance to perk up.

text.p: After a typically slow start to the week, issuers of both high-grade and high-yield corporate debt are expected to begin pricing new deals in the U.S. market on Tuesday, market officials said.
Syndicate officials said issuers, drawn by relatively low interest rates and strong investor demand, are likely to sell a substantial amount of new paper on Tuesday.

In the investment-grade sector, American General Corp is holding a 144a private placement offering of $500 million in capital securities via competitive bid for late Tuesday morning, market sources said.
The 49-year, bullet structure of the securities has been used by insurance companies before, syndicate officials said.
Also, Petroleum Geo-Services ASA is expected to sell $300 million in senior unsecured notes due 2007 via Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp on Tuesday, market sources said.
The company is a Norwegian offshore and seismological services provider.
In the junk-bond market, Anvil Knitwear Inc is expected to sell $130 million in 144a 10-year senior notes via DLJ, today. Price talk is around 10.75 percent, market sources said.
Also on slate for Tuesday is a 144a offering of 10-year notes from Dyncorp Inc via BT Securities Corp. Price talk is between 275 to 300 basis points, market sources said.
Returning to high-grades, Archer Daniels Midland Co may sell $300 million of 30-year non-callable debt as early as Tuesday via Salomon Brothers Inc, syndicate sources said.
Northwest Airlines is also rumored to be selling $250 million in seven or 10-year notes via Goldman Sachs & Co.
ABN-AMRO Bank is also expected to sell $250 milllion of perpetual securities, which are non-callable for 10-years, via Morgan Stanley & Co Inc, market sources said.
On tomorrow's agenda, Honeywell Inc is expected to sell $200 million in five-year and $200 milllion in 10-year notes via joint-lead managers Bear Stearns Co Inc and JP Morgan Securities Inc.
Price talk on the deal is 35 basis points over Treasuries for the five-year paper and 47 to 48 basis points over Treasuries for the 10-year paper, market sources said.
Market sources expect the deal to see strong demand from investors, as Honeywell, a well-known U.S. manufacturing company, is not a regular issuer in the corporate debt markets.
Honeywell makes automation and control systems for the home and areospace markets.
